title: Trump imposes 10% global tariff after stinging Supreme Court rebuke
subhead: On Friday, the US Supreme Court ruled that President Trump had exceeded his authority by imposing tariffs on virtually all US trading partners. Later in the day, Trump signed off on a global 10% tariff 'on all Countries, which will be effective almost immediately.'

title: Paris agricultural fair opens without famed cows as French farmers face multiple crises
Macron urges 'calm' ahead of march for slain far-right activist
How the Ukrainian army is standing up to Russia: 'Still being here four years after the attack is a victory'
subhead: Since the start of the Russian invasion in February 2022, Kyiv's troops have particularly relied on individual initiative and innovation to hold back Moscow's advance, despite a stark disparity in human and material resources.

title: 'In Minneapolis, ICE encountered a political history strong enough to generate a real balance of power'
subhead: The ability to withstand repression without weakening protest is a distinctive feature of Minnesota's political culture, writes historian Darius Devos for Le Monde.

title: In legendary Swiss village of Sils-Maria, the Chesa Marchetta hotel blends art with the art of living
subhead: Gallerists Iwan and Manuela Wirth chose the Swiss canton of Grisons to open their second location. They entrusted the restoration of this former mountain inn to architect Luis Laplace, who took care to remain faithful to the rustic spirit of the place while punctuating it with works of art.

title: Iran expert Ross Harrison: 'Cutting off the head of the snake' would not bring down the regime
subhead: Ross Harrison, a nonresident scholar at the Middle East Institute and an expert on the Islamic Republic, sees a growing likelihood of a US-led intervention aimed at causing the regime to implode. However, he believes the chances of success are limited, given the particularly 'resilient' nature of the Iranian system, as he explains in an interview with Le Monde.

title: Lyon mayoral election: Who's running?

From the Château de Versailles to the Elysée, the unshakable Catherine Pégard
subhead: Against all odds and well beyond her legal term, the former journalist who became adviser to President Nicolas Sarkozy held on as head of the Château de Versailles for 12 years. Forced out of her position in 2024, the skillful and tenacious Catherine Pégard quickly found a seat at the Elysée as culture adviser. Now, rumors suggest she could replace Rachida Dati, currently running for Paris City Hall, if she gives up her ministerial post.

title: Epstein files hand French prosecutors trove of new leads
subhead: The Paris prosecutor's office opened two investigations on Wednesday: one into 'human trafficking' and the other regarding 'financial offenses such as money laundering, breaches of probity, or tax fraud.'

title: Gaza's local authorities massively underreported deaths, says international research team
subhead: The first independent field study on Gaza to not involve local authorities, published in The Lancet Global Health on Wednesday, concludes that the number of violent deaths linked to the conflict has been underreported by about 35%.

title: 'The spectacle of European disunity in the face of pressure from both the United States and China is infuriating'
